sp.p: Oh does she so, Hell confound her for it; nay, Hands off, I'll follow you upon my Honour, where e'er you'll carry me.

sp.speaker: First Bayliff.
sp.p: Will you not send for Bail, Sir?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: No Sir, I'll directly to the Goal where I must lie.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: Will not my Bail be accepted? I'll willingly engage for one.

sp.speaker: Love.
Sir Rog.
sp.p: I'll strait away to this Alderman Saintly, and see what's to be done.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Farewel Sir, you'll find me at the Gate-House; come Sirs, conduct me where you will, I'll tamely follow; I think the Mystery is now disclos'd with a Vengeance.

div.stage: Enter Sir Charles Frankford, Charlot, Juliana and Bellisira.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Why should you delay my Happiness, dear Cozen, for the Punctilio of formal Courtship; I have long lov'd you, let that attone for it; and if my Sister does not flatter me, you do not hate me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What would the World, and you your self think of me, to catch at your first Proffer, as if I fear'd you would recant?

sp.speaker: Smiling.
sp.p: I dare trust your Constancy, and stay till 'tis convenient.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: To the World you may very well answer your Conduct; for it is but confirming the Reports which have been often of it, being so designed for me, 'tis what I beg of you; and what time's more convenient than now, at the consummating my Sisters Wedding?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Upon this condition, that you can oblige Sir Roger and my Cozen Bell. to marry at the same time I'll promise you.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Do you dispose her to it? I'll warrant him, for he is passionately in Love with her; what say you Cozen, will you obstruct my Bliss? for now it alone depends on you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You know, Sir Charles, you may dispose of me, who are my Guardian.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Now for some news from enchanted my Esquire.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: 'Tis done as you commanded; but 'tis well if you do not repent it, for I left him in a desperate Humour.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Good Heaven forbid! Sir Roger, pray wait on my Cozen Bell. to him, but do not you appear; by that time she has done, we'll all be there, (to Bell.) you have my full Directions.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Indeed, Sister, you have gone too far, in thus imprisoning a Man who shortly must command you. What is it you Design now? If you play him any further Pranks I'll betray you to him.

sp.speaker: Char.
Sir Char.
sp.p: Suppose he takes Cozen Bell. at her Word, what think you then?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Think! why, I shall think him a Man: But if he can resist the Temptation, an Angel.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Come, let us go. I'm very impatient to see him disabused.

sp.speaker: Turnkey.
sp.p: Sir, here is a Gentlewoman desires to speak with you; Shall I let her in?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: A Gentlewoman! Ay, pray conduct her in; this is a pretty Place to entertain Ladies in, but 'tis her own seeking; Who should it be? my fair Devil of a Wife perhaps!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: This is indeed amazing Goodness! How could you think of a lost Wretch, dear Madam, forsook by all the World?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not all you see, no my dear Lovewell, I never will forsake you, but constantly attend your Fortunes; mine cannot be favourable whilst yours are adverse; would you but make mine yours, as I will always espouse your Concerns, there should not be a Joy possest by Charlot, but what should be her Lovewell's, and all his Griefs be hers.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Your Generosity confounds me, I must not add so much to that vast heap of Favours I stand indebted to you for; I'm incapable any way to make the least return.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Is it so hard to Love? I have Youth and Fortune, is that no Charm?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Your Person is infinitely charming, and that more than Angel's Goodness, not to be resisted; but know, dear Madam, (sighsâ–ª) since I must tell you, to justifie my self from that Ingratitude, you justly might reproach me with; I am to my Destruction Married, Married, dear Lady; that's the curst cause of all my Misery.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then I am lost indeed, a fatal Moment that I saw you first; why were we born to be both unhappy?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I could, dear Madam, for ever be blest with you, but would not wrong your Goodness to involve you in my wretched ruin.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is meer excuse: But for all your Cruelty to me, I'll free you from this uncomfortable place, and if you'll still persist in your Ingratitude, expect the Curse that follows that base Sin of never being happy.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: For Heavens sake, dear Madam, stay and hear me speak.
sp.stage: [Following her to the Door. He returns.
sp.p: She's gone, and much I fear, will keep her word; had I but known her before I was bewitcht by that damn'd Sorceress, how happy might we both have been? But I'll no longer cavil with my Fate, but by a tame Submission to it ba â€¢â€¢ le its utmost Malice.

div.stage: Enter Sir Ro. Marwood and Charlot.
Lovewell starts up and throws away his Book.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Hah! What do I see! S'death 'tis the dear Devil her self; now shall I play the Fool and be again deluded, for I find I have not power to be heartily angry at her. But how came he with her?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: You seem surpris'd, Sir, I fear my sight offends you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I wish it ne'er had pleas'd me, (sighs) false Woman, of all the Coxcombs that this Town abounds with, Why was I cull'd out to be your Property! but tell me if thou hast so much Grace left to once speak Truth, how came he with you?

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: As a kind Friend should do to release thee of thy pains, and take them on my self; I love this Lady with all the Blindness which attends that Passion, marry her at any rate, and Sacrifice the World to give my self that Satisfaction. She has prudently consider'd your equal want of Fortunes will but make you both miserable.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Therefore if you'll consent to make void our Marriage, you shall this minute be releas'd from this place, if not, stay till Necessity compels you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Treacherous Man, how could you call me Friend, and thus basely betray me?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Well, what say you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Hell confound you both; no, I'll still keep thee to be reveng'd of thee, and plague thee for the Wrongs thou hast done me, ungrateful Creature, to torture thus a Man thou knowest lov'd thee from the first Moment he see that damn'd bewitching Face; wer't but honest, I could love thee still; but I will tear thee from my Heart and never think of thee again, (sighs) if possible; (she weeps) an stop those Crocodiles Tears, for though I know them to be so, they pierce me to the Soul.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Can you forgive me, Sir? for all this usage I long have lov'd you, which made me resolve some way or other to Marry you; how I effected it, I need not tell you, I had no sooner done it but I repented, believing justly you would be provoked to use me ill, when once you found I had only borrow'd the name of Charlot, this made me fly your anger.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: And to secure your self, secured me. Hah! was it so? I thank you kind Wife, indeed 'twas wonderous Love.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Pray hear me out. Sir Roger here, who has long solicited me to his unlawful Love, presuming on the Scantiness of my Fortune, when he found all other ways ineffectual to obtain me, proffered to marry me; which I likewise refused, acquainting him withal of my Marriage with you, which made him clap this Action on you, to drive you to the Choice of either renouncing me, or else to keep you here.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! that ever such a Piece of Villany should harbour in that Heart I always thought was Noble: How could you call me Friend, and thus betray me?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: aside. She makes me appear a pretty Rogue, that's the truth of it; but I must let her run on. You know, Mr. Lovewell, Love and Friendship are not compatible, where the Object of it is adored by both.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Then art thou Honest? Come swear and damn thy self, you know I am credulous, and shall believe you.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: By Heavens, and all that is Sacred, I am chast; and love thee at that extravagant Rate, I'd quit a Throne to dwell with thee in Chains, Oh my dear Lovewell, could you meet mine with an equal Passion, how happy might we be!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Yes, in some Country, where we could live by Air and Love; for I know not how we shall maintain a costlier Diet.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Providence will not let us starve, we must trust to that; I ask you nothing but your Love, I will maintain my self.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Indeed you wrong my Virtue, I'm truly honest, and would not injure you, though in a thought to gain the World; Forgive what's past, and take me to your bosom.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: holds her in his Arms. Heaven knows how willingly I could, yes, I could love thee, doat on thee, and be thy Fool.
Puts her from him. Stand off, vain easie Ass; what am I doing, trapanning of my self again?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: You shall not throw me from ye, I'll follow thus, (hangs on him) and never will forsake you; and here I swear I will not leave this place, till you conduct me hence.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: May I believe you serious?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: You must, you shall; I ever will be yours, with as much Truth as ever Turtle lov'd her dearest Mate.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well, I will live with thee, for Heaven knows I Love thee; and though you have used me thus, will always use you well.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: Smiling. So, Madam, I see I'm quite forsaken.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Here are more Witnesses to your bargain, Mr. Lovewell, th â€¢ n you are aware of; but methink, my new Brother, you might have askt me leave.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: O, Sir, do not triumph over the Easiness of a deluded Man; I humbly ask your Pardon for the Wrong I did design in marrying this fair Impostor, whom I did indeed believe your Sister; my love for her transported me beyond all thoughts of what I ow'd you.

div.stage: Sir Charles takes Charlot, and gives her to Lovewell.
div.p: Here, Lovewell, take her; for my sake use her well: I'll leave it to her to justify her Procedure to you. But upon my Honour she is my only Sister, the rich Heiress, Charlot, whom you first believ'd.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: The happy sequel does indeed make a large amends for all I have suffered: But are you sure we do not Dream? for I am so accustomed to Misfortunes I cannot yet believe them real.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: But you were not so diffident, Mr. Lovewell, before my Estate was added by my Brother's Discovery.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: An Estate to one in my Circumstances is no unwelcome Addition: But be assured, dear Madam, from the Sincerity I ever used to you, 'tis the least Part of my Joy; but I have, by my knowledge who you are, an unquestioned proof of your Virtue, and Sir Roger's being still my Friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: And so you shall always find me.
(To Bell.) For here's my Pretensions.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do you think, Sir Roger, I can so soon disingage (aside) my Heart from cruel Mr. Lovewell?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Fair cruel Lady! how could you torture so a wretched Man not then himself, with a pretended Love that gave me more disquiet than my own Troubles? But I am now all Joy, and will, unaskt, forgive the World and Fortune for all past Injuries; now my dear Charlot's mine, Heaven has not another Blessing left that I think worth the asking.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: You are wonderous Zealous now, pray Heaven it lasts.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: It must, it ever shall. How can you distrust my love, who have given you such evident Proofs of it?

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: Since Heaven is in this bounteous Humour of dispencing Blessings, why should it be only a niggard to me, and make me only a dull Spectator of your Happiness? Say; will not you join with me in my Suit to your fair Cozen here?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: She is my Charge, which here I resign to you. I know she'll be guided by my Advice; (Gives her to Sir Roger,) and now Cozen Juliana I claim your Promise.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Methinks you might stay till to Morrow, 'tis time enough, considering how long it is to last.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: No, we'll not trust the Treachery of another Day; Fortune is fickle, and may Frown to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Well then here's my Hand, From this Day forward, for better for worse, &c.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What think you of those Words, Sir Roger, do they not make you tremble?

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: Yes, for fear of some fatal Interruption before they come to be pronounced.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Let's lose no time then; I have a Friend will quickly dispatch the Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Ura.
sp.p: Well, Doll, what have you done with the 'Squire?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: As you commanded, Madam, conducted him to your Chamber, with charge not to speak but in a Whisper; and because I'd be sure he should discover nothing by his Candle, I took it away with me, for fear I told him it might be seen at Windows, which might occasion a Suspition; not being a Room in use, he readily consented; and said, he could find the way to Bed by dark, and slipt a Crown into my Hand to secure my Master not coming up.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: So 'tis well, there remains no more now; the House fills a Pace, but the Company I design to entertain with this Jest is Sir Charles Frankford, and Sir Roger Marwood, who have just sent to bespeak a Supper here. I'm sure they bring Company with'em, they have ordered such a noble one; we had best take Orders for it, and then we shall have time to entertain them.

div.stage: Enter Sir Charles, Sir Roger, Lovewell, Charlot, Juliana, Bellasira, Freeman and Urania.

sp.speaker: Ura.
sp.p: I've used all Methods to restrain his Folly, by shewing all the Scorn a virtuous Woman could to a dishonest Love; that but increased his Persecutions till I was weary of being Angry. I thought, by counterfeiting to return his Kindness, which his Vanity easily induced him to believe, I might draw him into some Snare to betray his lewd Intentions to the World, without the hazard of my own Reputation, which is generally sacrificed to the Malice of a disappointed Coxcomb. And to perfect my Revenge, I have contrived to let his Wife be witness to't, and so leave the Fool to her punishing, which he'll find Plague enough.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Call in Doll, and let's begin the Farce.
Come, Doll, to your Post.

sp.speaker: Aloud.
sp.p: Where's your Mistress, Doll?
Ha! what are you frighted at?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir, But I was almost Asleep, and you surprized me.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: That will not serve your turn, Mistress. What do you guard this Door so close for, is any Body in that Chamber?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: In this Chamber, Sir, no; who should be here?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Where is your Mistress, I say?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: My Mistress, Sir; in her Chamber not well; and gone to Bed.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No, but she is not; for, missing her, I have been to seek her, not only there, but in all the Rooms in the House, except this. Pray deliver the Key, without more Fooling; for I will see what you keep Century for.
So by this time I suppose the Fool is frighted enough.

sp.speaker: Aloud.
sp.p: Deliver it me, I say, you had best.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, don't fright me so, there it is.

sp.speaker: Freeman
sp.p: That shall not serve your Turn: I'll fetch you out of the Chimney here. Doll, bring my Pistols presently.

sp.speaker: 'Sq. W.
sp.p: within. O pray, Mr. Freeman, spare me this time, and you shall never catch me in your House again, nor with your Wife.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Come down then, or I'll fetch you, with a Pox to you.

sp.speaker: 'Sq. W.
sp.p: O pray, Mr. Freeman, have a little Patience, and I will.

div.stage: Enter Freeman pulling in 'Sq. W. wrapt in a Blanket.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay, nay, no Strugling; I must shew the Company my Wife's Gallant.

sp.speaker: 'Sq. W.
sp.p: aside. Who the Devil have I been with all this time? Here's Urania, now I find she fools me.

sp.speaker: To Ura.
sp.p: How dare you thus expose me; Do not you fear my Revenge?

sp.speaker: Ura.
sp.p: aloud. Not at all; I have Witnesses enough to prove both your Intentions and mine: But I have one within you know not of, whom I'll fetch to you.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Well, 'Squire Wouldbe, I hope hereafter you'll leave my Wife to such a poor clownish Fellow as my self; you see she does not understand your Merit, but thinks me good enough for her.

sp.speaker: Sq. W.
sp.p: aside. I am ashamed of my self, that's the truth of it, which makes me silent.

div.stage: Enter Urania, with Dowdy in a Night-Gown.

sp.speaker: Sq. W.
sp.p: My Wife! nay then I'm ruin'd past Redemption.

sp.speaker: Aside.
sp.p: How the Devil came she here? But that she has not Sense enough for an Intrigue, I should suspect she was as much mistaken in her Bedfellow as my self.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Have I catcht you, you Rebel you; I warrant you I'll do your Errand to my Mother.

sp.speaker: 'Sq. W.
sp.p: Nay, good Bunny, not so fast; pray let me know first how you came here a Bed with me.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Why, Dr. Partridge conjured me here on purpose to catch you.

sp.speaker: 'Sq. W.
sp.p: That's likely; you and I must come to a Reckoning about it.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Reckon me no Reckonings; there the Doctor can tell you as much.

sp.speaker: 'Sq. W.
sp.p: This Dr. Partridge! why, this is Freeman, the Master of this House. There is some Trick in this, (to Freeman.) I suppose you have been before hand with me, and given me the Horns I designed you.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: What do you mean by Horns? Do you think I'd be a Whore?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: 'Faith, 'Squire, no: You may keep your dainty Bit to your self; when I have a Mistress it shall be one that will have Wit enough to conceal what we do; for o' my Conscience she'd tell.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: aside. I cant't imagine how I came here, to say truth; for I thought I had been a Bed at home, till that Gentlewoman came and waked me, and bid me say what I did.

sp.speaker: Ura.
sp.p: You know, Esq Wouldbe, how many Disappointments I have given you just in the height of your Expectations, which would never perswade you was done in scorn of your lewd Design; this was the only way I thought would rid me of your Saucy Importunity. I did believe it very necessary to let you Wife be an Eye-Witness of your Faith to her, that she may hereafter take more than usual Care to keep her Coxcomb to her self; I will not give you the Satisfaction to let you know how I effected it, but if she or her Mother remembers, they may, I'll only add this; There has been no wrong offer'd to her Honesty, which you may easily believe, if you consider the Charms of her Wit and Person.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I think 'tis great pity they should not be intirely each others, for they are the best match'd Pair I ever saw.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Indeed, Urania, you are a Woman of a singular Virtue, that can resist the force of that tempting Mein and Air.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: Faith Sir, you'd better march off, these Ladies will be too hard for you else.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Ay, prithee Freeman, we have e'n enough of their Companies, dispose of them as you please.

sp.speaker: Esq W.
sp.p: aside. Gad I'd be reveng'd of her if I live.

sp.speaker: Freem to Esq W.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you may go if you please, and take your pretty Lady with you, your Cloths are in the Bar-room where you may dress you, there you have your Dismission from this Company.

sp.speaker: Ura.
sp.p: And what can you leave your dear Mrs. Honisuckle? tum d'ive I a Buss, sure you cannot think but I Love you strangly after all this Proof of my Kindness.

sp.speaker: Esq W.
sp.p: aside. P â€” x C â€” d ye, I could cry for Madness.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Ladies, your Servant; I thank you for all your Complements, and shall be very glad to see you at my House, (going.)

sp.speaker: Ura.
sp.p: Heark ye, pray take your Booby home with you, and see to keep him there.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: I'll have nothing to say to him, I'll go home to my Mother and tell her.

sp.speaker: Sir Char:
sp.p: Prithee put out the Coxcomb and bring some Musick with you; what think you Ladies of a Dance?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: With all our Hearts.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
You see what constant Things you Men are to your Vows, I war â€¢â€¢â€¢
this Fellow swore as much Faith and Constancy as any of you can.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Hang the Poor Animals, disgrace not so the Race of Men, to compare him to one; such sensless Wretches are only lumps of Dirt, not fit for any nobler Form.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: So, here's the Musick; what shall we Dance? the Brawls?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: No, by no means, Mr. Lovewell, not on our Wedding-Day, lest it prove an ill Omen.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Come, come; I'll lead up if you'll follow, every one take his Bride: Freeman, you and your Wife must make a Couple.

div.stage: They Dance, after which this Song.

lg.l: Look down great Hymen from Above,
These Pairs preserve in Peace and Love.
May never Jars their Joys molest,
But still a sweet and Halcyon rest
Upon their mutual Bliss attend,
And ev'ry Hour new Pleasures send.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: All Happiness to you all.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Supper waits you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Come, Ladies, let's in and take a short Repast; it grows late, and time to be at home, where indeed I ought to have given my Wife her Wedding Supper, but that the Warning was so short.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: At last the Storm is over blown,
And on that happy Coast I'm thrown
Where all my Joys are laid in store,
Heaven cannot give, nor could I ask one more.
